conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on blocks A and B, denote mass of block A as m_A and mass of block B as m_B.
Block A is on a horizontal ground, block B is in close contact with block A, and a horizontal force is applied to block B.
Block A is just about to slip, and block B is just about to slide down.
The maximum static friction force is equal to the sliding friction force.
Vertical forces on block A: weight of block A (m_A g), normal force from the ground (N_A), frictional force from block B (f_{BA}).
Horizontal forces on block A: frictional force from the ground (f_{A}), normal force from block B (N_{BA}).
Vertical forces on block B: weight of block B (m_B g), normal force from block A (N_{BA}).
Horizontal forces on block B: applied horizontal force (F), frictional force from block A (f_{AB}).
Block A is just about to slip, so the frictional force f_{A} is at its maximum value.
Block B is just about to slide down, so the frictional force f_{BA} is at its maximum value.
For block A: f_{A} = \mu_2 N_A.
For block B: f_{BA} = \mu_1 N_{BA}.
For block A: N_A = m_A g.
For block B: N_{BA} = m_B g.
For block A: f_{A} = N_{BA}.
For block B: F = f_{BA}.
Substitute frictional forces: \mu_2 m_A g = m_B g.
Substitute frictional forces: F = \mu_1 m_B g.
Solve for mass ratio: \mu_2 m_A = m_B.
The mass ratio m_A/m_B = 1/\mu_2.
